head.title: Compressed Data; A San Francisco Company Learns What a Mayor Can Do for Business

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: Compressed Data; A San Francisco Company Learns What a Mayor Can Do for Business

abstract.p: Photo of Mayor Willie L Brown of San Francisco is placed on the NetClerk Website, which some 750 local governments now use to issue construction permits online, along with a letter from him praising the company for helping reduce lines at city hall; photo (M)

block.p: More than 750 local governments now use the Web site operated by NetClerk to put the construction-permit process online. But so far, only the mayor of San Francisco, Willie L. Brown, has become part of NetClerk's advertising campaign.

Last week, NetClerk put a picture of Mr. Brown and the city's seal on www.netclerk.com, the company's Web site, along with a letter the mayor had written praising the company for, among other things, helping reduce lines at city hall.

More than 750 local governments now use the Web site operated by NetClerk to put the construction-permit process online. But so far, only the mayor of San Francisco, Willie L. Brown, has become part of NetClerk's advertising campaign.

Last week, NetClerk put a picture of Mr. Brown and the city's seal on www.netclerk.com, the company's Web site, along with a letter the mayor had written praising the company for, among other things, helping reduce lines at city hall.
So far, NetClerk's PermitCentral service has been used to issue more than 1,000 building permits in San Francisco.
''Although we enjoy interacting with each and every person who comes to city hall, waiting in line may not be the best use of a contractor's time,'' the mayor wrote.

The letter may have been less than a spontaneous testimonial. Jon Fisher, founder of NetClerk, said the company began discussing a ''public relations partnership'' with the San Francisco's mayor's office about a month ago.
So how does a letterhead partnership play out?

''The city of San Francisco is well known for its forward thinking, technological savvy,'' the mayor wrote. ''NetClerk offers a perfect example of how technology can improve a current system to the satisfaction of all parties involved.''
For Mayor Brown, of course, the satisfaction comes from bolstering his image as a technology supporter and promoter of the Bay Area's high-technology economy.
As it happens, NetClerk, based in South San Francisco, is part of that economy.
